ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: one on one small lessons
Mixture of virtual seminar and virtual lecture
One on one composition lessons with a teaching fellow
weekly lessons with TA
Lesson
There were also weekly private lessons.
virtual seminar, virtual private lessons
Weekly class was either a lecture, a presentation of what we'd been working on in our projects, or a guest presentation.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned so much about music notation! My notation details have been so sharply enhanced, and I feel a lot better prepared to approach engraving my music in the future. The weekly lessons are really helpful, and my TF taught me a lot about writing for specific instruments and about engraving. I also learned how to work with a film score in Sibelius, which will definitely be helpful in the future!
orchestration, diatonic modes and other scales, listening to contemporary guest composers
Instrumentation when scoring.
learned how to write for lots of instruments and different modes -- octotonic, diatonic modes, pentatonic, Whole-tone, etc.
Knowledge of how to actually compose (which I learned is rather different than knowing theory and analysis), knowledge of modes, modulation technique, percussion writing, Logic,
I learned a lot more about my compositional process and experimented more than I have in the past with writing modally. I was also exposed to lots of modern composers (with very different styles).
I learned various techniques to compose, and got experience doing it.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The weekly lesson aspect of the course was really enjoyable and super helpful, and I would not trade my experience in lessons for the world. I will say that the lectures felt a bit empty at times, and some of the lecture topics weren't that helpful (listing lots of percussion instruments, specific string bowing techniques). A lot of that information could have been conveyed by sending the students the powerpoint ahead of time, and then we would have had more time to do other things in lecture.

strengths: the weekly TA meetings are really helpful for the class assignments and for bouncing off ideas on your personal composition. some of the lectures, especially the ones about the different modes/scales were pretty helpful. I enjoyed doing the class assignments like the dorian on F and the canon.
weaknesses: this probably can't be changed but sitting in a lecture and paying attention for nearly two whole hours was difficult. I also wished we learned more theory.

Strengths: a lot of liberty with your own composition, which allow creativity to grow. Also was very cool to listen to the works of fellow classmates.
Weaknesses: sometimes guest lectures could be a bit disengaging, especially if you were not interested in that particular sector of music.
The weekly lessons are great! Dr. A is really fun! Some of the guests who come to talk to us feel like a distraction from the material

Strengths: really interesting and an amazing opportunity to be creative (which is more rare than one might think), learned so much about how to actually be a composer and what it takes
Weaknesses: can be extremely intimidating if you have never composed before or have relatively less theory knowledge because even though its Comp Seminar I, almost everyone has done some composition already, 

Something that is both a strength and a weakness is that It is very self motivated and self paced, which I enjoyed but others may not

The lessons are easily the best part of this class. I got extremely specific feedback on timing, formatting, musical ideas, orchestration, etc.

The lectures about instruments and music theory sometimes felt a bit slow, although the reference slides were helpful.

Weekly composition lessons are amazing, guest presentations with the School of Music composition students were always super interesting and enjoyable. Lectures on the course material (mainly focused on pandiatonicism, studying different instruments) introduced me to plenty of new compositional tools, but I wish there were more musical examples (or a deeper discussion of those techniques) so that we could see how they could be employed. (For instance, we would be presented with the notes and chords found in the octatonic scale, but wouldn't cover any music that uses it or know what makes it interesting/useful).

The lessons were great! I think it'd be nice if the discussions on our projects in class were a little more constructive. People don't often know what types of comments and it's not always very helpful. Sometimes it is, though, which makes me think that some structure would help a lot.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The class worked well over Zoom, although it was difficult to do the film scoring project without access to the music lab on campus. A bit more guidance on how to use specific softwares would have been nice. I also imagine it might have been difficult for some students to purchase expensive notation software for the film scoring project.
Honestly it was the best it could get given it's a music class online. I don't really have any improvements to suggest since I thought it was fine.
I loved the lessons. Class was fun and nice to hear so many different composers, although I learned mostly by doing

The virtual lessons via Zoom worked surprisingly well and honestly felt no different than in-person composition lessons.

I thought technology was used intelligently during the lectures and seminars, too. Maybe it's something about composers and their tech skills, but I encountered fewer Zoom glitches in this class than in any of my others.
It was fine!

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, if you're interested in composing. You'll get a lot of very specific feedback on the notation of your pieces, which might feel annoying in the beginning but will turn your music into professional quality appearance-wise in no time!
I would recommend this course if you're interested in working on a personal composition and getting one on one feedback. You also get to listen to a bunch of guest composers.
Yes! Such a great way to receive credit for composing music. Also learn a lot of composing skills that you can incorporate into your own work.
Yes! This is one of the best classes I've taken at Yale!!

Yes! If you want to learn to compose absolutely!! If you just casually want to "compose music" with no ideas of what that music might look like, maybe not - it takes a lot of independent thought and ideas to actually compose your own piece of music and the class really isn't designed to give you those ideas

Yes, if you already have done a bit of composing and would like to keep working on writing music. Much of the growth I did in this class was independent and self-motivated, so I probably wouldn't recommend MUSI 320 to someone who does not (or will not) choose to compose on her own time.

Yes! Weekly composition lessons were the highlight of my semester, I had an amazing TA who was a great fit for my compositional style and I felt like I came out of every single lesson with thoughtful feedback and a new tidbit of wisdom. Composition exercises were always helpful with figuring out how to employ the material we'd learn in lecture, and the final group project of scoring a movie scene was lots of fun. However, I felt that I had less freedom with the kind of semester-long project I could work on compared to Comp II (project requirements are more strict, and the composition exercises take away time/energy from working on your main project. Not necessarily a critique, just a difference between Comp I and II). My only gripe is that Dr. A can sometimes be a little blunt in her evaluations (she's not afraid to tell you she thinks your submission is bad). As someone who is still pretty new to composing, hearing too much of it can be a bit discouraging, and made writing more difficult and stressful. If you really care, though, it'll certainly push you.
Yes, if they want to write music! This course forces you to do that, and quite a bit of it. For me, being told to write music is the only way I can do enough of it to really improve, and told I was.
